.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.1.name: hrSystemUptime
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.1.description: The amount of time since this host was last initialized. Note that this is different from sysUpTime in the SNMPv2-MIB [RFC1907] because sysUpTime is the uptime of the network management portion of the system.

.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.2.name: hrSystemDate
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.2.description: The host's notion of the local date and time of day.

.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.3.name: hrSystemInitialLoadDevice
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.3.description: The index of the hrDeviceEntry for the device from which this host is configured to load its initial operating system configuration (i.e., which operating system code and/or boot parameters). Note that writing to this object just changes the configuration that will be used the next time the operating system is loaded and does not actually cause the reload to occur.

.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.4.name: hrSystemInitialLoadParameters
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.4.description: This object contains the parameters (e.g. a pathname and parameter) supplied to the load device when requesting the initial operating system configuration from that device. Note that writing to this object just changes the configuration that will be used the next time the operating system is loaded and does not actually cause the reload to occur.

.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.5.name: hrSystemNumUsers
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.5.description: The number of user sessions for which this host is storing state information. A session is a collection of processes requiring a single act of user authentication and possibly subject to collective job control.

.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.6.name: hrSystemProcesses
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.6.description: The number of process contexts currently loaded or running on this system.

.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.7.name: hrSystemMaxProcesses
.1.3.6.1.2.1.25.1.7.description: The maximum number of process contexts this system can support. If there is no fixed maximum, the value should be zero. On systems that have a fixed maximum, this object can help diagnose failures that occur when this maximum is reached.
